questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of a patient presenting with a snake bite?

ASV: Anti-snake venom

choices.text: The use of tourniquets is not recommended
The bitten limb should be immobilized
ASV should be administered only if there are signs of envenomation
ASV should be administered locally to prevent local toxic effects of the toxin

questions.solution:
Local administration of Anti-snake venom (ASV) to deal with the local toxic effects of toxin is not recommended as it is ineffective, may cause pain, and may lead to compartment syndrome.

Anti-snake venom is the mainstay of treatment of snake envenomations. It is administered intravenously as the unbound toxin can only be neutralized in the bloodstream or tissue fluid. Intramuscular injections of ASV are also not recommended as its absorption may be retarded by hypovolemia induced by venom. ASV can cause anaphylactic reactions and is thus used only if there are signs of envenomation (Option C). ASV administration should be followed with careful monitoring to detect signs of anaphylaxis.

Systemic signs of envenomation are:

  • Evidence of coagulopathy: detected by clotting tests
  • Evidence of neurotoxicity: signs like muscle paralysis, ptosis, and ophthalmoplegia.
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities: signs like shock, hypotension, and arrhythmias.
  • Persistent and severe vomiting or abdominal pain.

ASV administration will also be required in cases of local signs like rapidly spreading swelling or swelling involving more than half of the affected limb.

The first aid following a snake bite consists of the mnemonic: carry no right. 

Carry: The victim is not allowed to walk, even for a short distance. Walking generates muscle-pumping activity which disperses the venom into the systemic circulation.

No: No tourniquet, no electrotherapy, no cutting, no pressure immobilization, no suction to the bite site. (Option A)

R: Reassure the patient since 70% of the bites are from non-venomous species.

I: Immobilize in the same way as a fractured limb. A splint can be applied to the bitten extremity to limit movement and assist with positioning. The extremity should be maintained in a neutral position at approximately heart level. (Option B)

GH: Get to a hospital immediately. The most important step is to rapidly transport the patient to a medical facility equipped to provide supportive management.

T: Tell the doctor of any systemic symptoms which may have appeared on the way to the hospital.

questions.text: A resident asks you to assist while performing an e-FAST on a patient with multiple rib injuries due to an RTA. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this procedure?

choices.text: Abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium are assessed
It is reliable in detecting even less than 100 mL of free blood
It is unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
e-FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.

e-FAST (extended-focused assessment with sonography for trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Disadvantages:

  • It is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.
  • Does not directly identify injury to the hollow viscus.
  • Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma.
  • It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

If there is a doubt, eFAST may be repeated or supplemented with other investigations.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presented with acute, severe abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting. She had one episode of bloody stools. Examination reveals hypoactive bowel sounds and mild abdominal distension. Which of the following investigations is likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of atrial fibrillation, severe abdominal pain, bloody stools, and hypoactive bowel sounds, is likely to have acute mesenteric ischemia. The investigation likely to confirm the diagnosis is CT angiography.

Acute mesenteric ischemia occurs when there is an imbalance between splanchnic perfusion and intestinal metabolic demand. The three causes of mesenteric ischemia are:

  • Arterio-occlusive ischemia
  • Nonocclusive ischemia
  • Mesenteric venous thrombosis. 

This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which is likely the source of the embolus that led to intestinal ischemia. Other risk factors for arterio-occlusive ischemia are recent myocardial infarction, valvular heart disease, and recent cardiac catheterisation. 

The intestines have widespread collateral formation to reduce the effects of ischemia. However, two areas - Griffith's point (splenic flexure) and Sudeck's point (sigmoid flexure) are areas with decreased blood flow. These areas are the meeting point for collateral vessels and, thus, are most at risk for intestinal ischemia. 

Acute mesenteric ischemia usually presents with severe, acute abdominal pain that is out of proportion to the abdominal examination. There may also be nausea, vomiting, transient diarrhoea, anorexia, and bloody stools. There may also be mild abdominal distension and hypoactive bowel sounds. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is CT angiography. If it is acute, angiography can be done during the laparotomy as it is an emergency condition. Treatment involves resection of the dead bowel and restoring blood flow. 

Other options: 

Option A - Abdominal X-ray will reveal gas under the diaphragm in case of hollow viscous perforation. However, this finding is non-specific and can occur in any abdominal viscus perforation. 

Option C - Cardiac enzymes will be elevated in myocardial infarction. This patient has mesenteric ischemia. 

Option D - An electrocardiogram may help rule out acute myocardial infarction and for diagnosing atrial fibrillation in this case. It would not confirm a diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: A nulliparous female with a history of infertility presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and sudden onset of acute abdominal pain. Her serum hCG is 2500 IU. A diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Since the patient has ruptured ectopic pregnancy it should be managed immediately by surgery and the most appropriate management is salpingectomy.

In salpingectomy, the fallopian tube which has ruptured is removed from its uterine attachment with bipolar cautery. It can be done for both ruptured and unruptured ectopic pregnancy. But linear salpingostomy can be done only in case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Here the products of conceptus are removed through a small incision on the antimesenteric border of the fallopian tube and it is left unsutured.

Management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy includes expectant, medical, and surgical management options.

Expectant management - an observation with serum β-HCG monitoring.

Indications:

  • Initial serum hCG level < 1,500 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestation sac size less than 4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS 
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
  • Hemodynamically stable

Medical management - systemic use or direct local use of chemotherapeutic drugs

  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (MTX 50 mg/m^2 single dose intramuscularly), potassium chloride, prostaglandin, hyperosmolar glucose, actinomycin.
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-HCG.

Indications:

  • The patient is hemodynamically stable
  • Serum hCG level less than 5,000 IU/L
  • Tubal diameter less than 4 cm without any fetal cardiac activity
  • Absence of any intra-abdominal hemorrhage

Surgical management - laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, microsurgical laparotomy 

Indications:

  • Cases that don't fit the medical therapy criteria
  • Serum β-HCG levels are elevated despite medical therapy
  • Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

Estimation of serum β-HCG should be done weekly till the value becomes less than 5.0 mlU/mL, following conservative surgery or medical treatment.

questions.text: A 3-year-old unimmunized child is brought to the emergency room with high-grade fever, drooling of saliva, and dysphagia. Auscultation revealed inspiratory stridor. His lateral X-ray of neck is given below. The next best step in his management is?

choices.text: Secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone
Give antipyretics and reassure the patient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, drooling, dysphagia, and inspiratory stridor along with the lateral X-ray neck showing the thumb sign suggests acute epiglottitis. The next best step in his management is to secure airway and start empirical IV ceftriaxone.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammatory condition of supra-glottic structures, i.e. epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoid. It is also known as supraglottic laryngitis and is a medical emergency. 

It commonly affects children aged 2–7 years. The most common organism responsible for this is Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib). 

Clinical features include high-grade fever, dysphagia, drooling of saliva, sore throat, dyspnea, and inspiratory stridor.The patient usually adopts a tripod position by leaning forward on his arms and has his neck extended with his chin up and breathing through the mouth. Airway obstruction occurs due to inflammation and edema of the surrounding structures. 

The direct laryngoscopic shows an inflamed and swollen epiglottis that has a characteristic cherry-red-colored appearance. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign (shown below). 

Treatment includes: 

  • Immediate hospitalization 
  • Securing airway by endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or by tracheostomy, irrespective of the degree of respiratory obstruction
  • Empirical management by third-generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime, ceftriaxone) or ampicillin
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Humidified oxygen can also be given

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his right scrotum. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum with an absent cremasteric reflex. On Doppler ultrasound, there is an absence of arterial flow to the right testis. Surgical exploration is done and the testis was not necrotic. What is to be done for the testis in the contralateral scrotum?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy presenting with acute pain in the scrotum, absent cremasteric reflex, and absent arterial flow on doppler is suggestive of testicular torsion. During surgical management of testicular torsion, orchiopexy at the same sitting is to be done for the contralateral testis which is viable.

Testicular torsion is a condition where the blood supply to the testis is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord resulting in ischemia of epididymis and testis. The condition is most common in adolescent males. The risk factors for torsion testis are undescended testis, testicular tumor, and bell-clapper deformity of the gubernaculum.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, apyrexia. Testis seems to be high in the scrotum and the tender, twisted spermatic cord can sometimes be palpated. The cremasteric reflex is lost on the side of the affected testis.

A diagnosis is arrived at primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning shows absent or decreased intratesticular blood flow compared to the contralateral side.

Immediate scrotal exploration is indicated even if there is a doubt regarding the diagnosis. An incision is taken along the midline (median raphe) or bilateral scrotal incisions are taken.

Surgical placement of the testicle in the scrotum is called orchidopexy (or orchiopexy). It is primarily used as a procedure to correct undescended testis but it is also used in testicular torsion.

Initially, the testis is detorsed and an intraoperative Doppler ultrasound is done. If the testis is found to be viable, a three-point fixation with non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea and dartos fascia of the testis is done to prevent recurrence. 

In the same exploration, orchiopexy should be done to the contralateral testes to prevent future contralateral torsion as there is a chance for the same anatomical deformity to be present in the contralateral side.

Other options:

Options A and D: Contralateral testis will be at high risk of torsion in the future. Hence, orchidopexy has to be done in the same surgical exploration.

Option B: Orchidectomy is preferred in non-viable or necrotic testes.

questions.text:
An elderly woman is rushed to the emergency room following an episode of syncope. Her caretaker reports that the patient had multiple episodes of loose stools and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her blood investigations and ECG are given below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Serum sodium: 140 mEq/L
Serum potassium: 7.1 mEq/L
Serum chloride: 100 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen creatinine ratio: 26.9
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the ECG showing tall T waves in all the leads and the laboratory investigations showing serum potassium of 7.1 mEq/L are suggestive of hyperkalemia. The next best step in the management is intravenous calcium gluconate.

This patient has acute kidney injury resulting from dehydration. Her BUN: Creatinine ratio is 26.9 which is >20:1 which suggests prerenal azotemia. Acute kidney injury results in impaired excretion of potassium resulting in hyperkalemia.

Although ECG changes are not specific and hyperkalemia may occur without significant ECG changes, the typical changes seen in ECG due to hyperkalemia are sequential and include:

  • Peaking of the T waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Widening of the PR and QRS intervals
  • Sine waves
  • Ventricular fibrillation and asystole

The presence of cardiac toxicity is a serious manifestation of hyperkalemia and requires immediate cardiac stabilization with intravenous calcium gluconate. Calcium gluconate should also be initiated in all patients with serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L and patients with muscular weakness.

The recommended dose is 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate infused intravenously over 2–3 min with cardiac monitoring. The dose should be repeated if there is no change in ECG findings or if findings recur after stabilization.

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

Other options:

Option A: Patiromer is a potassium-binding drug that can be used in chronic hyperkalemia. It doesn't play a role in acute hyperkalemia due to acute kidney injury like in this patient. Sodium zirconium cyclosili­cate and sodium polystyrene are other potassium-binding agents.

Option C: Hemodialysis may be needed in patients with acute or chronic renal failure to remove excess potassium, especially in patients who are oliguric. However, it should be undertaken after cardiac stabilization.

questions.text:
A known type 1 diabetic patient presented to the emergency with abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea. He reports having missed his insulin dose. DKA is suspected in him. So an ABG is taken and a fluid infusion is started. Insulin administration is not given until ABG reports are available. What could be the possible reason for delaying insulin?

DKA: Diabetic ketoacidosis

ABG: Arterial blood gas analysis

choices.text: Insulin alters the values in ABG analysis

questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a likely diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) that could be associated with hypokalemia. Insulin causes potassium uptake by activating Na-K+ ATPases which may worsen hypokalemia.

DKA is an acute, severe, hyperglycemic disorder, which was considered a hallmark of type 1 diabetes, but can occur in type 2 diabetes as well. Inadequate administration of insulin (especially during times of physiologic stress like infections) may precipitate DKA.

Features of DKA include:

  • Nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain
  • Hypotension and tachycardia
  • Hyperglycemia, glycosuria, and ketosis
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

As a physiologic response to acidosis, the body loses potassium and there is total body potassium deficit. Serum potassium might be normal or elevated, despite total body potassium deficit.

The initial treatment in DKA is fluid administration (first normal saline, then half-normal saline, then dextrose+ half- normal saline). Insulin has to be given once potassium status is known. If insulin is administered prior to potassium correction, it would worsen the preexisting hypokalemia.

Management for DKA is as follows:

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The device is an Automated External Defibrillator (AED).

This is a special medical device that is commonly used for recognizing the absence/presence of rapid ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. With no need for intervention by an operator, it determines whether an electrical shock right to the heart must be performed (defibrillation).

An automated external defibrillator can be used on those victims, who are unconscious and aren’t breathing in a normal way. As a rule, it is used together with CPR in cases of sudden cardiac arrest. It is forbidden to use it on patients who are less than eight years old or those weighing less than 25 kgs.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a gun-shot wound. He has a BP of 90/50 mm Hg and his heart sounds are not audible on auscultation. Another examination finding would be noted in which of the following structures to complete the triad of cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
The triad of cardiac tamponade is known as Beck's triad that includes hypotension, elevated JVP, and absent/muffled heart sounds. The component missing in the above scenario is the jugular venous pressure (JVP), which is ideally examined in the internal jugular vein (IJV).

IJV lies near to the anterior of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It should be examined in good light at 45° of tilt. It reflects the right atrial pressure unless the superior vena cava (SVC) is obstructed. 

The external jugular vein might also show distention in cardiac tamponade but it should not be used for measuring JVP as it can be compressed as it passes under the clavicle.

Note: if the question mentions decreased air entry or breath sounds on one or both sides, pneumothorax may be suspected.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after being rescued from a burning house where he was trapped for 4 hours. The patient has a few minor burns but is coughing extensively. His voice is hoarse and he is able to drink water with some difficulty. What is the safest strategy of management?

choices.text: O2 therapy with well-fitting face mask

questions.solution:
For a patient who presents with a history or suspicion of inhalational burn injury, elective endotracheal intubation is the safest strategy.

Delay can make intubation very difficult because of airway edema and can lead to airway obstruction. One should be ready to perform an emergency cricothyroidotomy if intubation is delayed.

Recognition of the potentially burned airway:

  • A history of being trapped in the presence of smoke or hot gases
  • Burns on the palate or nasal mucosa, or loss of all the hairs in the nose
  • Deep burns around the mouth and neck

American Burn Life Support (ABLS) indications for early intubation include:

  • Signs of airway obstruction (hoarseness, stridor, accessory respiratory muscle use, sternal retraction)
  • The extent of the burn (TBSA > 40%–50%)
  • Extensive and deep facial burns
  • Burns inside the mouth or difficulty swallowing
  • Significant edema or risk for edema
  • Signs of respiratory compromise: Inability to clear secretions, respiratory fatigue, poor oxygenation or ventilation
  • Decreased level of consciousness where airway protective reflexes are impaired
  • Anticipated patient transfer of large burn with airway issue without qualified personnel to intubate en route

questions.text: A 34-year-old  male patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain. The patient gives a history of recurrent episodes of epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few months. The supine abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the characteristic sign shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign. It is seen in the pneumoperitoneum. 

The acute presentation of abdominal pain with similar episodes in the past, along with the given abdomen x-ray suggests pneumoperitoneum. Bilateral subphrenic free air is seen and the arrow mark shown here is the falciform ligament. This peritoneal fold is an embryological remnant of the umbilical artery connecting the anterior abdominal wall to the anterosuperior surface of the liver. It is invisible under normal situations; however, when surrounded by intraperitoneal free air, it may become visible as a vertical band of soft tissue parallel to the right border of the spine.

Causes of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel perforation
    1. Peptic ulcer
    2. Ischemic bowel
    3. Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Small bowel perforation
    1. Trauma
    2. Penetrating injuries
  • Injury during surgery/laparoscopy

Radiological signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament–related signs
    • Football sign - the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline, seen on chest x-ray.
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Periportal free gas sign

Other options: 

Football sign - Supine radiograph where the peritoneal layer is enhanced over the entire abdominal cavity. This is seen in a large pneumoperitoneum. 

Cupola sign - Free air below central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline

Lateral umbilical ligament sign (or inverted 'V' sign) is seen in the pelvis representing free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man, who had attended his retirement party, came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. Fundoscopic examination shows a picture similar to the one given below. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). 

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Clinical features

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe edema- the whole retina looks white in color
  • Marked attenuation of arteries - thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein - cattle-track appearance

Fundoscopy may also show Hollenhorst plaque. Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: An elderly man, who is a known case of diabetic nephropathy, presented to the emergency with palpitations and chest discomfort. ECG showed tall T-waves. Laboratory investigations showed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs will cause the shift of potassium back into the cell?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with ECG showing tall T-waves and elevated serum potassium levels are suggestive of hyperkalemia. Epinephrine will cause the shift of potassium back into the cell.

Epinephrine is an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1, and beta 2 receptors.

The β actions are mediated through cAMP. Epinephrine binds to Gs → ATP and is broken down to cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. This results in:

  • In the liver and muscle- hyperglycemia and hypokalemia due to potassium uptake in muscle and liver
  • In adipose tissue- increased plasma free fatty acids
  • In the heart- an increased force of contraction reinforces the positive inotropic action
  • In pancreatic islets- increases glucagon secretion

Epinephrine is used in anaphylaxis, to prolong the action of local anesthetics, cardiac arrest, and as inhalational epinephrine in the treatment of post-intubation and infectious croup.

Epinephrine is contraindicated in anesthesia with halothane due to the risk of arrhythmias and in patients receiving beta-blockers because a marked rise in BP can occur due to unopposed alpha action.

Hyperkalemia refers to an increase in the levels of serum potassium >5.5mEq/L.

The image given below shows sequential ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is a medical emergency and has to be treated when ECG changes are present or severe hyperkalemia (serum K+ >6.5) without ECG changes. Management is as follows:

  • Intravenous infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate for 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. It helps to antagonize the cardiac effects.
  • Intravenous regular insulin 10 units followed by 50mL of 50 % dextrose. This helps in shifting the plasma K+ into the cells.
  • Nebulisation with β2 agonists such as albuterol or salbutamol.
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics, and/or dialysis are useful to remove the excess potassium.

questions.text: The table shows the examination findings of various psychiatric emergencies presenting with fever and altered sensorium. Which of the following is corresponding to the findings seen in serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option (B) i.e. row 2 has findings corresponding to Serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is a serious condition occurring due to serotonin overstimulation. Clinical features include diarrhea, restlessness, agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability with fluctuations in vital signs, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

It can occur with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options-

Option (A): Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a rare condition that occurs on administration of neuroleptic (antipsychotic) drugs. It presents with autonomic instability, hyperpyrrexia, rigidity, and delirium. Sustained rigidity leads to muscle breakdown and elevated creatinine kinase levels. NMS will not show the hyperreflexia and clonus seen in serotonin syndrome. The causative drug should be stopped immediately and treatment can be started with dantrolene and bromocriptine.

Option (C): Anticholinergic syndrome can occur due to concurrent use or use of higher doses of strong anticholinergic drugs like cyproheptadine or diphenhydramine. It will present with anticholinergic symptoms like blurring of vision, dry mouth, constipation, etc. Hyperreflexia and hypertonia would not be seen in this condition. 

Option (D): Malignant hyperthermia is seen in the setting of neuromuscular blockade administration in the operating room, such as succinylcholine. It presents with elevated body temperature, muscle rigidity, hypotension, muscle breakdown, etc. The drug of choice to treat this condition is intravenous dantrolene.

 

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

 Syndrome
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome
Anticholinergic syndrome
Malignant hyperthermia
 Cause
Dysregulation of dopaminergic pathways
Co-prescription of MAO-I and SSRIs leading to increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels

questions.text: A 22-year-old female is brought to the casualty with seizures for the past 10 minutes. History from relatives suggests no seizure-free intervals in the past 10 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals of the patient, which is the first drug you administer to the patient?
questions.solution:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first drug used in the management is lorazepam.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, it is defined as any one of the following:

  • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or
  • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures.

questions.text: An unconscious patient of head injury comes in the casualty. On examination there is raised intracranial pressure. Which anesthetic agent is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is contraindicated in raised intracranial pressure.

Ketamine is a direct cardiac-depressant by inhibiting Ca2+ channels, but this is masked by its indirect sympathomimetic action which may cause

Increase in all pressures like ICT, IOP, BP and hence contraindicated in:

  • Raised intracranial pressure/pathology with mass effect/ head injury
  • Hypertension, Ischemic heart disease, arterial aneurysm
  • Open eye injury, glaucoma or vitreoretinal surgery
    • Most potent bronchodilator with intact upper airway reflexes. Hence anaesthesia of choice in asthma (status asthmaticus).
    • Increased BP, CO, HR, cardiac metabolism, oxygen demand
    • Increased cerebral blood flow/ metabolism/ oxygen consumption and seizures.
    • Increases muscle tone and is an arrhythmogenic.
  • Preferred anaesthetic agent in head injury:
    • Thiopentone (Cerebro protective)
    • Propofol
    • Etomidate (protects against circulatory depression)
    • Isoflurane

questions.text:
A patient is brought to the emergency room with polytrauma. Which of the following is not considered as an adjunct to the primary survey?

AP- Anteroposterior

PA- Posteroanterior
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray PA view is not a part of a primary survey. Chest X-ray is done in AP view in primary survey of trauma care.

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat life-threatening conditions.
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate). If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion). Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation). This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale along with pupil reactivity score (GCS-P).
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey: These help in the evaluation of other life-threatening processes.

Monitoring- 

  • Electrocardiograph (ECG) is done to evaluate cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade.
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring to detect any changes in heart rate and rhythm.
  • Continuous oxygen monitoring via pulse oximetry.
  • Ventilation monitoring via capnography and arterial blood gas analysis.

Catheters-

  • Urinary catheters help in the evaluation of fluid status.
  • Gastric catheters decompress the stomach and reduces the risk of aspiration.

Imaging-

  • Trauma triple radiographs of the cervical spine, chest, and pelvis, even in pregnant women. 
    • Cervical spine lateral view to look for spinal injury.
    • Chest AP view is done to evaluate for pneumothorax, hemothorax, rib fractures, or aortic injury.
    • Pelvis AP view to evaluate for pelvic fractures.
  • Ultrasound FAST Examination is the "Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma". It is performed to detect pericardial and intraperitoneal blood. The Extended FAST (E-FAST) includes examination of the thoracic cavity.
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is done to detect intraperitoneal bleed.
  • Emergency computed tomography (CT)

These specialised forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerised tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey, and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

Laboratory studies-

  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess oxygentaion, ventilation, and pH.
  • Blood typing and grouping for blood transfusion.
  • Complete blood count and coagulation studies in anemic patients or patients using anticoagulation drugs.
  • Pregnancy test in any woman of child-bearing age.
  • Urinalysis in pelvic or abdominal trauma.
  • Urea and electrolytes, blood glucose levels, and toxicology studies in patients with unexplained altered mental status.

questions.text:
A middle-aged male patient comes with complaints of generalized weakness and palpitations. ECG showed ST depression and QT prolongation. He was diagnosed to have hypokalaemia and started on potassium supplementation. However, the patient's symptoms persisted. What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?

ECG - Electrocardiography
questions.solution:
In a patient with hypokalemia, the most likely cause of treatment failure is hypomagnesemia. 

Hypomagnesemia leads to reduced cellular uptake as well as increased renal secretion of potassium by the distal nephron, causing treatment refractoriness.

Hypokalemia occurs when the plasma concentration of potassium is less than 3.5 mM. It can occur due to:

  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Beta-2 agonistic drugs
  • Insulin
  • Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis
  • Total parenteral nutrition
  • Hypothermia
  • Magnesium deficiency
  • Diuretics (except potassium-sparing agents)
  • Mineralocorticoid excess
  • Renal tubular syndromes (Gitelmen's, Bartter's, and Liddle's syndrome)

Hypokalemia causes life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias. ECG shows broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation that is most marked when serum K+ <2.7 mmol/L (shown below). 

It also causes weakness and paralysis. Paralysis of intestinal smooth muscles can cause intestinal ileus. Sodium chloride and bicarbonate retention lead to metabolic alkalosis. Other functional effects include polyuria, phosphaturia, and hypocitraturia.

Oral potassium supplementation is the mainstay of treatment (IV supplementation is reserved for severe complications such as paralysis and arrhythmias). Hypomagnesemia should also be looked for and treated. 

Other options:

Option B- The clinical features of hyponatremia are predominantly neurological as a result of the development of cerebral edema. Patients usually present with nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, brainstem herniation, and coma.

Option C- The most notable clinical features of hypermagnesemia are vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade. Early signs include hypotension refractory to vasopressors and volume expansion.

Option D-  The clinical features of hypernatremia are neurological. The most frequent manifestation is altered mental status that ranges from confusion and lethargy to deep coma.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. Evaluation reveals hypotension, tachycardia and decreased pulse pressure. The FAST scan reveals massive intraabdominal bleeding. He receives 5 units of packed red blood cell transfusion in the next hour. Which of the following complications is least expected to be seen in this patient?
  1. Hypokalemia
  2. Hyperkalemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypercalcemia
  5. Hyperthermia
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a patient of RTA with hypotension and decreased pulse pressure is suggestive of haemorrhagic shock. The patient is probably seeping into hypovolemic shock. The patient who received 5 units of packed red blood cell transfusion(pRBCs) in 1-hour also indicates massive blood transfusion. Hyperthermia and Hypercalcemia are least likely seen after massive blood transfusion. 

Hypocalcemia is a known complication of massive blood transfusion and not hypercalcemia. This is due to the citrate toxicity of transfusing stored blood. Hypothermia is due to the opening up of coelomic cavities and infusion of cold blood (refrigerated). 

The classification of haemorrhagic shock, the compensatory mechanisms seen in shock and the expected electrolyte abnormalities in a massive blood transfusion are all enlisted in the pearls attached below. 

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal
